content.text: The student ensures that the metre ruler is horizontal
Briefly describe how to check that the ruler is horizontal. You may draw a diagram

The student adjusts distance \(d\) between the \(0.0 \text{cm}\) mark and the \(1.50 \text{N}\) load, as shown in Fig. 1.1. He moves the thread supporting the \(1.50 \text{N}\) load so that it is at the mark on the metre ruler shown in Fig. 1.2
The metre ruler is **not** drawn to scale
Record the distance \(d\) indicated on Fig. 1.2
The reading on force meter X is shown in Fig. 1.3
Record \(F_{X}\) , the reading on force meter X shown in Fig. 1.3

The student moves the \(1.50 \text{N}\) load to distances \(d = 10.0 \text{cm}\) , \(30.0 \text{cm}\) , \(50.0 \text{cm}\) , \(70.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\) . For each distance \(d\) , he reads the value \(F_{\text{X}}\) on force meter X
His readings are shown in Table 1.1
Plot a graph of \(F_{\mathrm {X}}/\mathrm {N}\) (y-axis) against \(d/\mathrm {cm}\) (x-axis). Start the axes at the origin (0,0)
Draw a best-fit straight line
From your graph, determine \(F_0\), the value of \(F_{\mathrm{X}}\) when \(d = 0.0 \mathrm{cm}\)
Calculate the weight \(W_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the metre ruler, using the equation \(W_{\mathrm{R}} = 2 \times F_0\)
State and explain whether your plots made it easy to choose the best-fit line
Justify your answer with reference to your plots
statement
explanation
Another student does the experiment with the same equipment. He reads values of \(F_{\mathrm{X}}\) which are all higher than those in Table 1.1 by 0.05 N
Suggest **one** reason for this difference. Assume that the values in Table 1.1 are accurate
A student investigates the forces supporting a metre ruler to determine the weight of the metre ruler
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1. The scale of the metre ruler faces upwards
Record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.1
The student pours hot water into the beaker and records the initial temperature \(\theta\) in Table 2.1. She then records the temperature \(\theta\) every 30 s. Her values are shown in Table 2.1
Describe **one** technique that you use to ensure that temperature readings in this type of experiment are as accurate as possible
Estimate what the temperature \(\theta_{300}\) is at 300s. Use the readings from Table 2.1 to guide you
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first 90s of the experiment. Use the readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{0}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 90 \text{s}\)
Include the unit for the cooling rate
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the middle 90s of the experiment. Use the readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{3}\) during the last 90s of the experiment. Use the readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) and \(\theta_{270}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 180 \text{s}\) and \(t = 270 \text{s}\)
Use your results from (d) to describe the overall pattern of the rate of cooling of the water in the experiment. Justify your answer by reference to your results
Estimate the final temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) of the water after several hours
Another student does the same experiment. He starts with the hot water at a lower initial temperature
Suggest how his cooling rates are likely to compare with those in (b). Use your results to explain your answer
suggestion
explanation
State one variable, other than the initial water temperature, that the student needs to control
[Total: 11]
A student investigates the cooling of hot water in a beaker
She uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1
On Fig. 3.1, complete the circuit to show a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference (p.d.) across the terminals P and Q. [1]
Read, and record in the first line of Table 3.1, the values of \(V\) and \(I\) shown on the meters in Fig. 3.2 and Fig. 3.3
The student rearranges the resistors between terminals P and Q, as shown in Fig. 3.4, to form circuit B and circuit C. The new values of \(V\) and \(I\) are shown in Table 3.1
For each circuit, calculate and record in Table 3.1 a resistance \(R\). Use the values of \(V\) and \(I\) in Table 3.1 and the equation:
The student measures the potential difference \(V\) across the parallel combination of resistors \(\mathsf{R}_1\) and \(\mathsf{R}_2\) and measures the current \(I\) in the circuit
His readings are shown in Fig. 3.2 and Fig. 3.3
Calculate resistance \(R_{\mathrm{A}}\). Use the value of \(R\) from circuit A and the equation:
Record resistance \(R_{\mathrm{B}}\). \(R_{\mathrm{B}}\) is equal to the value of \(R\) from circuit B
Calculate resistance \(R_{\mathrm{C}}\). Use the value of \(R\) from circuit C and the equation:
A student suggests that \(R_{\mathrm{A}}\) , \(R_{\mathrm{B}}\) and \(R_{\mathrm{C}}\) should all be equal
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your statement with reference to values from your results
statement
justification
The circuits use a 3V power supply
Briefly explain why resistor \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{p}}\) , shown in Fig. 3.1, must remain in place throughout the experiment
\(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{p}}\) has a resistance of \(4.0\Omega\) . Use Fig. 3.3 and the values in Table 3.1 to support your answer
Draw the circuit symbol for a variable resistor
Briefly explain **one** advantage of using a variable resistor to control the current
[Total: 11]
A student determines the resistance of \(\mathsf{R}_1\) . He uses a variable resistor in circuit B to control the current and draws a graph of \(V\) against \(I\)
A student investigates circuits containing different combinations of resistors
Circuit A is shown in Fig. 3.1. Circuit A is not complete
A student investigates the refraction of light
Refraction is the change in direction of a ray of light when passing into a transparent substance, as shown in Fig. 4.1
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how the concentration of a gel affects the angle at which light is refracted when passing from air into the gel
A transparent gel block can be made by dissolving gel powder in hot water in a mould and allowing it to cool. Changing the amount of powder will change the concentration
Concentration is measured in \(\text{g} /\text{cm}^3\)
The apparatus available includes:

• samples of gel made at different concentrations and labelled with those concentrations
• a ray-lamp which produces a narrow ray of light
In your plan:
• list any additional apparatus needed
• explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take
• state the key variable to keep constant
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
• explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
